timeline.author: normanmaurer

timeline.message:
Improve MqttMessageType::valueOf cost

Motivation:

MqttMessageType::valueOf has O(N) cost

Modifications:

MqttMessageType::valueOf uses a const lookup table

Result:

MqttMessageType::valueOf has O(1) cost

timeline.bodyText: What about simple switch statement? In that case we don't need to create and hold static variable.
timeline.author: doom369

replies.bodyText:
I see some reasons, the switch statement is:

tied to the encoding of MqttMessageType (if the type will change, you'd need to change both, but is very unlikely to happen)
is likely using many branches that the JVM will try to order accordly to some profiling/counter policy (for no reasons, given that this is for pure encoding reasons)
has a bigger byte code size, reducing the chances to be inlined or that its caller will be inlined when compiled into a bigger method

In general I see that the lookup tables perform a bit better for cases like these, but I haven't produced a reliable bench yet for this one to be 100% sure
The second statement could be not precise if the JIT Is going to produce a jump table in ASM but still the other statements apply.
replies.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText: I see from http://hg.openjdk.java.net/jdk8/jdk8/hotspot/rev/34bd5e86aadb that C2 should generate a jump table in ASM here (using jmpq with x86 CPUs) due to the number of choices, saving the binary jump table approach that wouldn be used otherwise: I admit I am curious to check how it perform vs this PR, given that jmpq should perform an unconditional jump not getting any misprediction cost...
replies.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText: @franz1981 so you want to pull this in or do some more experiments first ? I am cool with both btw
replies.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: My test shows that switch is faster rather than static field array access (probably because you do the bounds checks in merthod + most likely JVM does that). However, your comment regarding byte code size may be valid. So you need to check that with full decoder flow to prove that.
replies.author: doom369

replies.bodyText: Let me try writing a small bench here bud: I see other points on MQTT where enums valueOf lookup could be simplified like this and it's used on the hot paths.
replies.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText:
@doom369
Re

My test shows that switch is faster rather than static field array access

That surprise me: the pattern of message types you've used to perform the lookup is long enough to trick the branch predictor?
I see that can make a lot of difference while dealing with real use case vs synthetic workload

However, your comment regarding byte code size may be valid

Yep, I have been recently bitten by inlining budget/threshold exhaustion with Netty (see #10368)
replies.author: franz1981
doom369

timeline.bodyText: you can use for each here
timeline.author: doom369

timeline.bodyText: This is going to cause a lot of contention on this.next. Why not just use a for loop and iterate over all of them, instead of trying to do measure just a single one?
timeline.author: alblue

replies.bodyText:
I've tried that here: #10400 (comment)
And the results gotten were quite similar: on b30c74b instead you can check the "wrong" version of the benchmark on #10400 (comment), because not using BlackHole on each iteration can cause the for loop to get unrolled, making the getViaArray to look better then it is.
I'm still not 100% sure if I should use #10400 (comment) or this benchmark (using the & trick) TBH...

his is going to cause a lot of contention on this.next.

wdym with contention?
replies.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText:
I think your approach with the blackhole.consume() in the for loop is probably the right one, in that it shows that when you iterate over multiple values (and you consume the results) then the lookup through the array is faster than looking up with the switch.
This approach (reading/writing the local state) might end up being an unnecessary overhead, and you'll have a lot of write traffic happening on each loop. I still don't see the benefit in trying to benchmark each lookup individually, when you can lookup in a for loop (with bh.consume) and it will give you the data that suggests array lookups are faster than switch statements.
replies.author: alblue

replies.bodyText:
Yep, agree, you've convinced me: trying to get numbers for the single case isn't meaningful for the purpose of the benchmark and it just create unneeded noise in the results :+1
Let me send a new commit with very last iteration of the bench, thanks for good advices :)
replies.author: franz1981

replies.bodyText:
@alblue if the state scope it Thread there should be no contention. The risk with writing loops into benchmarks is that either:

You'll get loop unrolling
You'll get OSR compilations

Resulting in confusing results. I have used the "one element" benchmark in the past with no issues. The overhead of elements load is very small and easily measurable, so I would generally go for that method rather than the loop.
A further point for consideration is using the "alternative" blackhole method (a dontinline empty method), which might be appropriate given the very small operation we are examining here.
I think there's no point to invest further in measurement here, but commenting for feedback/clarity.
replies.author: nitsanw
franz1981
